title: Section 351 IPC - Assault
summary: Defines assault as gesture or act causing apprehension of force.
content: Whoever makes any gesture or preparation intending or knowing it to be likely that such gesture or preparation will cause any person present to apprehend that he is about to use criminal force, is said to commit an assault.

title: Section 352 IPC - Punishment for Assault
summary: Punishment for assault without grave provocation.
content: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation, shall be punished with imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine up to five hundred rupees, or both.

title: Nature of Offence
summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.
content: Section 351/352 IPC offences are cognizable; police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.

title: Bailability
summary: Non-bailable offence.
content: Section 351/352 IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

title: Trial Jurisdiction
summary: Triable by Court of Session.
content: Section 351/352 IPC offences are triable by the Court of Session due to seriousness.

title: Witness Testimony
summary: Witness testimony with corroboration strengthens prosecution.
content: Eyewitness accounts and corroboration are essential to establish guilt in assault cases.

title: Medical & Forensic Evidence
summary: Expert medical/forensic reports crucial for proof.
content: Medical reports and forensic analysis establish the nature of injury, cause, or identity of accused in assault cases.

title: Mens Rea & Actus Reus
summary: Both mental and physical elements required.
content: Court assesses intention (mens rea) and the act (actus reus) to establish liability for assault.

title: Section 307 IPC - Attempt to Murder
summary: Section 307 IPC criminalizes attempt to murder. Intention and overt act are sufficient for conviction, even if death does not occur.
content: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge, and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of murder, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and if hurt is caused to any person by such act, the offender shall be liable either to imprisonment for life, or to such punishment as hereinbefore mentioned. Attempts by life-convicts: When any person offending under this section is under sentence of imprisonment for life, he may, if hurt is caused, be punished with death.

title: Section 300 IPC - Murder Definition
summary: Section 300 IPC defines murder by intention, knowledge, or imminently dangerous acts.
content: Except in the cases hereinafter excepted, culpable homicide is murder, if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as the offender knows to be likely to cause the death of the person to whom the harm is caused, or if it is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, or if the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death, or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid.

title: Section 302 IPC - Punishment for Murder
summary: Section 302 IPC prescribes punishment for murder: death penalty or life imprisonment with fine.
content: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Section 308 IPC - Attempt to Commit Culpable Homicide
summary: Section 308 IPC punishes attempts to commit culpable homicide not amounting to murder; lesser threshold than Section 307 IPC.
content: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of culpable homicide not amounting to murder, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both; and, if hurt is caused to any person by such act, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Nature of Offence - Cognizable
summary: Cognizable offence: police can act directly without magistrate approval.
content: Section 307 IPC is classified as a cognizable offence under CrPC. Police may register FIR, investigate, and arrest without prior approval from a Magistrate.

title: Bailability - Non-bailable
summary: Non-bailable: bail is discretionary, not a right.
content: Section 307 IPC is a non-bailable offence. Accused has no absolute right to bail; bail is at the discretion of the court.

title: Trial Jurisdiction - Court of Session
summary: Triable only by Court of Session.
content: The offence is triable exclusively by a Court of Session given its gravity. Magistrate may take cognizance, but trial is committed to the Court of Session.

title: Medical Reports & Expert Testimony
summary: Medical expert evidence helps prove seriousness of injuries and intention.
content: Medical officersâ€™ reports on injuries, weapon impact, and causation are admissible as expert evidence. Courts rely on doctors to establish whether the injuries inflicted could have been fatal.

title: Corroboration of Witness Testimony
summary: Eyewitness testimony must be corroborated.
content: Eyewitness accounts are strengthened when supported by medical or forensic evidence. Corroboration is essential in serious cases.

title: Confessions
summary: Confessions admissible only if voluntary and properly recorded before magistrate.
content: Confessions must be voluntary and not induced by threat or promise. Confessions to police are inadmissible unless made before a Magistrate.

title: Definition & Ingredients
content: Attempt to murder involves an act with intention or knowledge that, if death had resulted, it would amount to murder. Ingredients: (i) act by accused; (ii) intention/knowledge; (iii) proximate step toward death.

title: Distinction with Related Offences
content: Section 307 vs Section 302: attempt vs completed murder. Section 307 vs Section 308: different thresholds of intention. Grievous hurt may also attract Section 307 if intent to kill is proven.

title: Mens Rea & Actus Reus
content: Courts consider nature of injury, weapon used, body part targeted, motive, and circumstances to infer intention (mens rea). Actus reus requires a proximate overt act toward causing death.

title: Section 120B IPC - Punishment for Criminal Conspiracy
summary: Defines punishment for conspiracy to commit serious offences.
content: Whoever is a party to a criminal conspiracy to commit an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for a term of two years or upwards, shall be punished in the same manner as if he had abetted such offence.

title: Nature of Offence
summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.
content: The offence under Section 120B IPC is classified as cognizable, meaning police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.

title: Bailability
summary: Non-bailable offence.
content: Section 120B IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

title: Trial Jurisdiction
summary: Triable by Court of Session.
content: Due to seriousness, Section 120B IPC offences are triable by the Court of Session.

title: Witness Testimony
summary: Witness testimony with corroboration strengthens prosecution.
content: Eyewitness accounts and corroboration are essential to establish guilt.

title: Medical & Forensic Evidence
summary: Expert medical/forensic reports crucial for proof.
content: Medical reports and forensic analysis establish the nature of injury, cause of death, or identity of accused.

title: Mens Rea & Actus Reus
summary: Both mental and physical elements required.
content: Court assesses intention (mens rea) and the act (actus reus) together to establish liability.

title: Section 299 IPC - Culpable Homicide
summary: Defines culpable homicide by intention or knowledge causing death.
content: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits culpable homicide.

title: Section 300 IPC - When Culpable Homicide is Murder
summary: Defines when culpable homicide amounts to murder.
content: Except in cases excepted, culpable homicide is murder if done with intention of causing death or injury likely to cause death.

title: Nature of Offence
summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.
content: The offence under Section 299/300 IPC is classified as cognizable, meaning police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.

title: Bailability
summary: Non-bailable offence.
content: Section 299/300 IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

title: Trial Jurisdiction
summary: Triable by Court of Session.
content: Due to seriousness, Section 299/300 IPC offences are triable by the Court of Session.

content: Eyewitness accounts and corroboration are essential to establish guilt.

title: Mens Rea & Actus Reus

title: Section 499 IPC - Defamation
summary: Defines defamation and its scope.
content: Whoever, by words either spoken or intended to be read, or by signs or visible representations, makes or publishes any imputation concerning any person intending to harm, or knowing that such imputation will harm, the reputation of such person, is said to defame that person.

title: Nature of Offence
summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.
content: The offence under Section 499 IPC is classified as cognizable, meaning police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.

title: Bailability
summary: Non-bailable offence.
content: Section 499 IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

title: Trial Jurisdiction
summary: Triable by Court of Session.
content: Due to seriousness, Section 499 IPC offences are triable by the Court of Session.

content: Eyewitness accounts and corroboration are essential to establish guilt.

title: Section 359 IPC - Kidnapping
summary: Defines two types of kidnapping.
content: Kidnapping is of two kinds: kidnapping from India, and kidnapping from lawful guardianship.

title: Section 362 IPC - Abduction
summary: Defines abduction as forceful or deceitful inducement to move.
content: Whoever by force compels, or by deceitful means induces any person to go from any place, is said to abduct that person.

title: Nature of Offence
summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.
content: The offence under Section 359-374 IPC is classified as cognizable, meaning police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.

title: Bailability

content: Section 359-374 IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

title: Section 302 IPC - Punishment for Murder
summary: Prescribes punishment for murder: death penalty or life imprisonment with fine.
content: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Trial and Bailability
summary: Non-bailable, cognizable, tried by Sessions Court.
content: Murder is a cognizable, non-bailable offence triable by a Court of Session.

title: Ingredients of Murder
summary: Defines mental and physical elements of murder.
content: Murder requires intention or knowledge of likely death and actus reus causing death.
